problem.markdown:
>>Upon irradiation of electromagnetic radiation, fluorescence is the phenomena of emission of usually:<< (x) Higher wavelength light ( ) Higher wavelength electron ( ) Higher wavelength x-ray ( ) Lower wavelength electron
>>Fluorescence microscope is type of:<< (x) Optical Microscope ( ) Electron Microscope ( ) Atomic Force Microscope ( ) Scanning Tunneling Microscope
>>Excitation and Emission spectra are nearly:<< ( ) Similar in shape with respect to each other (x) Are mirror image with respect to each other ( ) Similar in intensity with respect to each other ( ) Are inverted with respect to each other
>>Duration of Fluorescence phenomena is:<< ( ) 10<sup>3</sup>-10<sup>0</sup> s ( ) 10<sup>0</sup>-10<sup>-3</sup> s ( ) 10<sup>-3</sup>-10<sup>-6</sup> s (x) 10<sup>-6</sup>-10<sup>-9</sup> s
>>In fluorescence, nuclei stained through Bis-benzimidazole derivative (Hoechst 33258) appears:<< ( ) Red ( ) Green (x) Blue ( ) Purple
>>TIn fluorescence, cytoskeleton stained through Phalloidin derivative (Alexa Fluor 488) appears:<< ( ) Red (x) Green ( ) Blue ( ) Purple
>>In fluorescence, mitochondria stained through MitoTracker (CMXRos) appears:<< (x) Red ( ) Green ( ) Blue ( ) Purple
>>Using fluorescence microscopy, which of the following can be observed:<< ( ) Contact angle of cells (x) Cells and its microscopic components ( ) Surface topography of cells ( ) All of the Above
>>How can the cells per unit area be quantified from fluorescence microscopy images:<< ( ) Cannot be quantified ( ) By counting cells in a high magnification (a few cells) image in a given area ( ) By counting cells in a low magnification (hundreds of cells) image in a given area (x) By counting areal density of cells using many images
>>Fluorescence microscopy will be able to tell whether a material is cytocompatible:<< ( ) Yes, cytocompatibility can be clearly confirmed ( ) Yes, cytocompatibility can be easily quantified (x) Yes, can provide an indication through in vitro tests ( ) Yes, and needs no confirmation via in vivo tests

Similar in intensity with respect to each other

problem.p: How can the cells per unit area be quantified from fluorescence microscopy images:

choicegroup.label: How can the cells per unit area be quantified from fluorescence microscopy images:
choicegroup.choice: By counting cells in a high magnification (a few cells) image in a given area
By counting cells in a low magnification (hundreds of cells) image in a given area
By counting areal density of cells using many images

problem.p: Fluorescence microscopy will be able to tell whether a material is cytocompatible:

choicegroup.label: Fluorescence microscopy will be able to tell whether a material is cytocompatible:
choicegroup.choice: Yes, cytocompatibility can be clearly confirmed
Yes, cytocompatibility can be easily quantified
Yes, can provide an indication through in vitro tests
Yes, and needs no confirmation via in vivo tests
